run.lit: This is a good read about PHP OO Good habits
Encapsulate your code - having to change things in many places is a pain
Write highly cohesive code by using strongly named grouping patterns - reuse is the goal
Make it DRY - If you see it appear a second time then make it so it will only have to be changed in one place
Indent calculation code using hard tabs (no spaces) for better readability in the calculation dialog box.
When editing code within the calc dialog box you can use Option-Tab (Mac) or Control-Tab (Win) to insert tabs
No trailing white space after lines of code.
are named using a single word in Title case and should not be represented by attributes. (e.g. "Employee" is an attribute of "People" and "Schedule" is a group of "Events")
(used for solution data) use camelCase starting with a lowercase letter
summary fields are prefixed by the word "summary" and their type before their identity
Note you can identify this as a summary of a foreign key because of the underscore
the universal temporary Global field is named CLIPBOARD within any table
unstored calculated fields and non-data fields (those used for UI/Utility purposes) are prefixed with the percent sign and use camelCase
The primary key in each table is simply named "id" - Fields are identified by FileMaker inherently by the TableName::id nomenclature.
Primary keys should use a UUID value (by custom function or plugin) via auto-enter and do not use FileMaker's serial value option.
Using a UUID addresses any issues with importing and forgetting to modify any serial number - Just make sure to not perform auto-enter on import.
Foreign keys within any table are named using an underscore followed by the lowercase version of their Title case table name. (e.g id_table). Only foreign keys use the underscore.
The underscore within the field name distinguishes a foreign key from the camelCase field names
locally scoped variables ($variableName) use camelCase. Similar to fields, it's the $ which distinguishes them.

global variables ($$VARIABLE.NAME) are capitalized and use domain specific prefixes relevant to their functional use within the solution. Each level of the domain is delineated using dot notation (a period).
are always prefixed with their "base table" name and separated using the » character ( Right-pointing Double Angle Quotation Mark – \x00BB ) using a space on either side of the ».
which are dedicated for internal development and have no relationships are prefixed with the @ symbol and one space
This sorts developer table occurrences at the top of the list for selecting tables
when used for a portal on a layout, are indicated using the Vertical Line ( known as bar or pipe ) on either side of the name

are prefixed according to their use within the solution. Prefixes, of which there can be multiple levels, are delimited by a single colon. Suggested approach is to use the "base table" name as the initial prefix.
are prefixed by their corresponding reserved name.
Reserved object prefixes are the following
are named using a prefix which corresponds to the functional relevance to which they belong.
are named in the familiar FileMaker format of TitleCamelCase.
Any returned result in your code, which is boolean, is written using FileMaker's support for "True" and "False" instead of using return values of zero (0) and (1). This increases readability of code.
Always use a single space between the ampersand and the concatenated parts to improve readability.
Exception Note: When simply adding a single carriage return using the pilcrow, combine all elements together.
Use a space before and after operators
Use one space between function name and opening parenthesis
This facilitates easy selections within both Windows and Macintosh when double-clicking to highlight
(optional) Remove the space between each argument and it's trailing semicolon
This increases readability by reducing excessive spacing
If statements start their test argument on the same line as the declaration and complex statements should be broken down in to multiple lines.
) // each result should be on it's own line
) // embedded functions use indenting so the outer function can still be identified
When boolean operators are used, they should, when possible, precede the line they are connected to.
If ( Evaluate( "Let ( [" & var.contents & "]; False )" ) = "?" // generates an error or
If ( Evaluate( "Let ( [" & var.contents & "]; False )" ) = "?" or var.empty or var.missingParams;...

Case statements provide their tests and results on individual lines. Result values are indented from their test. Each new text/result should be separated by at least one blank line. Complex calculations can identify their using a comment on the first line of the result or using a blank line between the test and result.
False // default result on it's own line
False // default result on it's own line
Let functions within only one variable declaration can defined on one line
Let ( var.someVar = Table::fieldName ; If ( var.someVar = "Active" ; True ; False )
Let functions with multiple variables include the opening parenthesis and bracket on the same line
Closing Let variable declarations end on their own line. This indicates the start of the result.
Calculation scoped variables use camelCase and are identified by a preceding variable indicator of "var."
This makes it easy to distinguish calculation variables from custom function arguments, $variables and Table::fieldNames
Use present tense verbs or adjectives to indicate Boolean variable status on both calculation and locally scoped variables.
Empty strings should not be used within calculations. A blank custom function named "null" should be created and used for empty values (*see note below)
Within solution code this increases code readability and distinguishes literal values and escaped text from empty values.
"Good code should be easy to read";
Note the above function uses another custom function which simply returns a tab character in order to improve readability
"Good code should be easy to read";
Exception Note: Code within a custom function can and should use double quotes for empty values "". This decreases custom function dependencies on the "null" function.
Use modified conventions outlined in Doxygen
C style comments (/* */) and standard C++ comments (//) are both fine, though the former is discouraged within functions (even for multiple lines, repeat the // single-line comment).
* (bool) True or False based on proper
* Try to always use the List() function when
* variable used when you wish to enforce *
* that inbound parameters match the name of
* the script. It is reset after the *
No objects are referenced within calculation code via literal strings or absolute names. The ObjectID custom function is used to reference to FileMaker objects.
If [ Get ( LayoutName ) = ObjectID ( 37; "Layout"; null; null ) ] Go To Layout [ "XYZ" ]
Note: The Go To Layout script step shows a literal layout because FileMaker handles any updates via internal id references
If [ Get ( LayoutName ) = "People: Customer List" ] Go To Layout [ "XYZ" ]
Field sorting order within the fields tab are arranged using the View by "custom order" option. When arranging table occurrences on the graph, they are placed based on the "custom order" setting.
